questions.text: A veterinarian with fever, chills, and myalgia is diagnosed with Q fever. Which of the following is the most common reservoir of this disease?
questions.solution:
Ticks are the most common reservoir of Q fever.

Coxiella burnetii is the causative pathogen. The most commonly identified sources of human infection are farm animals, such as cattle, goats, and sheep.

Infected mammals shed C. burnetii in their urine, feces, milk, and placenta. Human exposure to C. burnetii may occur as a result of inhalation of contaminated aerosols arising from the placenta or parturient fluids of infected livestock or from contaminated secretions on the surface of newborn animals.

People working with farm animals and veterinarians are at a higher risk of infection.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

Arthropod Disease transmitted
Anopheles mosquito Malaria, Filariasis
Culex mosquito Bancroftian filariasis, Japenese encephalitis, West nile fever, Viral arthritis
Aedes mosquito Yellow fever, Dengue, Chikungunya, filariasis, zika
Mansoni Mosquito Filariasis, Chikungunya
Housefly Typhoid and paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar(Visceral Leishmaniasis), oriental sore, Oroya fever, Sandfly fever
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness(African Trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus(Murine Typhus), hymenolepis diminuta
Black fly(Simulium) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug(Kissing bug/triatominae) Chagas disease(American Trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick (Ixodes species) Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, viral hemorrhagic fever,(e.g. Kyasanur forest disease), tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, lyme disease
Soft Tick (Argas species) Q fever, relapsing fever, Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) (can be casued by hard tick as well)
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus, Rickettsial pox
Itch mites Scabies
Cyclops Guinea-worm disease, fish tapeworm (D. latum)
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrance, Jiggar, Chigoe flea)  Tungiasis, Ulcer in the feetnails

questions.text: Which of the following is not transmitted by hard ticks?
questions.solution:
Relapsing fever is not transmitted by hard ticks, but by soft ticks.

questions.text: Peripheral smear of a patient with high grade fever, arthralgia, and myalgia is given below. Which of the following transmits this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with peripheral smear showing maltese cross appearance is suggestive of babesiosis. It is transmitted by ticks.

questions.text: A patient with fever and joint pain presented with the following lesion on his left leg. Which of the following transmits this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing bulls eye rash is suggestive of Lyme disease. It is transmitted by Ixodes tick.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the vector in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a soft tick. It can withstand starvation for over a year.

The head of the soft tick lies ventrally and it does not have a scutum. It serves as a reservoir for Q fever and transmits relapsing fever.

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the vector in the given image?

choices.text: Its nymphal stage has seven stages
It lays hundreds of eggs at once

questions.solution:
The given image is of a hard tick. The hard tick has only one nymphal stage.

It has a hard chitinous shield called the scutum which covers the entire back in males a small portion in the front in females. It feeds night and day and cannot withstand starvation. It lays several hundreds or thousands of eggs in one sitting.

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.

Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: Which of the following are also known as chiggers?
questions.solution:
Larval forms of trombiculid mites are also known as chiggers.

They are spider-like arthropods which are vectors for scrub typhus. The image given below shows trombiculid mite.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by the vector shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a reduviid bug. It transmits American trypanosomiasis, also known as Chagas disease.

Reduviid bug is also known as the kissing bug or triatomine bug. It lives in cracks, fissures and other spaces in the walls and ceilings of human dwellings. Residual spraying with HCH or dieldrin is used for the control of these bugs.

Option B: African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) is transmitted by the tsetse fly.

Option C: Onchocerciasis is transmitted by the blackfly (Simulium). 

Option D: Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is transmitted by the sandfly.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with complaints of nocturnal pruritus. Examination shows burrows over the skin of his hands. KOH mount prepared from these lesions is given below. Which of the following vectors transmits this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and KOH mount showing the itch mite are suggestive of scabies. It is transmitted by itch mite or Sarcoptes scabiei.

The female parasite burrows into the epidermis where it breeds. It is a small parasite, barely visible to the naked eye, with 4 pairs of legs.

Its life cycle consists of four stages—egg, larva, nymph, and adult stages. Its spread can be through close contact or contaminated clothes.

Benzyl benzoate is very effective as a sarcopticide. HCH, tetmosol, and sulphur ointments are also used.

The image given below shows itch mite.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by mites?
questions.solution:
Kyasanur forest disease is not transmitted by mites. It is a viral hemorrhagic fever transmitted by hard ticks.

Scabies, scrub typhus, and rickettsial pox are transmitted by mites.

questions.text: You are given the following slide during your community medicine practicals. Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by this vector?
questions.solution:
The above image is of a head louse. It does not transmit endemic typhus which is transmitted by fleas.

Lice transmit epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, and trench fever.

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by lice?
questions.solution:
Epidemic typhus is transmitted by lice and caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

Murine typhus is transmitted by the rat flea. Tick typhus is transmitted by a hard tick. Scrub typhus is transmitted by trombiculid mite.

Related Pearl: Lice

    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)

  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.

  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not transmitted by lice?
questions.solution:
Q fever is not transmitted by lice. It is spread by the inhalation of contaminated aerosols containing Coxiella burnetti.

Soft ticks are the most common reservoirs of Q fever. The aerosols arise from the placenta or parturient fluids of infected livestock or from contaminated secretions on the surface of newborn animals.

questions.text: Identify the following vector which transmits murine typhus.
questions.solution:
The given image is of a rat flea-Xenopsylla cheopis. It transmits murine typhus.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by rat fleas?
questions.solution:
Pneumonic plague is not transmitted by rat fleas. It is transmitted by inhalation of aerosolized droplets.

Rat fleas are vectors for murine or endemic typhus, bubonic plague, and hymenolepiasis caused by Hymenolepis nana and Hymenolepis diminuta.

questions.text: A flea survey is being conducted in an area prone to outbreaks of plague. Which of the following indices is not used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Incidence of plague is not an index used in flea surveys. Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are:

  • General flea index
  • Specific flea index
  • Percentage incidence of flea species
  • Rodent infestation rate

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about sand fleas?
questions.solution:
Sand fleas cause ulcers in the feet.

They are also called jigger or chigoe fleas. The species called Tunga penetrans is of particular importance as it causes tungiasis.

The fertilized female burrows into the skin of the feet, often beneath the nail and causes ulcers. Tetanus and gas gangrene frequently occur because of secondary infection.

They flourish best in sandy soil and are found in the western parts of India.

The below image shows a sand flea.

questions.text: Which of the following is transmitted by the vector shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a cyclops or water flea. It is the vector for guinea worm disease or dracunculiasis and fish tapeworm infection.

Humans are infected with these diseases by drinking water that contains cyclops. Its average life span is 3 months. 

Physical methods like straining and boiling of water can ensure the killing of this organism. Chemicals that can be used to control cyclops are chlorine, lime, and abate. Biological methods include Gambusia fish and barbel fish.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not associated with rodents?
questions.solution:
Ascariasis is not associated with rodents.

Diseases related to rodents are:

  • Bacterial -
    • Plague
    • Tularemia
    • Salmonellosis
    • Leptospirosis
    • Rat-bite fever
  • Viral -
    • Lassa fever
    • Encephalitis
    • Hemorrhagic fever
  • Rickettsial -
    • Scrub typhus
    • Endemic typhus
    • Rickettsial pox
  • Parasitic -
    • Hymenolepis diminuta
    • Leishmaniasis
    • Amoebiasis
    • Trichinosis
    • Chagas disease
  • Fungal -
    • Histoplasmosis
    • Ringworm
